overview: The purpose of this Act is to establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the second and fifth circuits. [3] This measure was amended to delete language that would have established a program in the Third Circuit, instead requiring the Third Circuit and Big Island Drug Court to conduct an interim study for a future program. [4] The judiciary is required to submit annual reports on the pilot program, which is scheduled to be repealed on June 30, 2028. [3]
appropriations: The bill appropriates unspecified sums from the general revenues for fiscal years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027 for the Judiciary and the Department of Health. [3] A committee report requests the Committee on Finance to consider an appropriation amount of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) to the Department of Health. [4] This request includes $145,000 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) for a clinical psychologist, $76,788 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) for a social worker, and $45,216 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) for a social services assistant. [4]
assumptions_and_methodology: The bill does not specify the methodology for its blank appropriation amounts. [3] The committee report provides a cost breakdown for the Department of Health positions, suggesting the appropriation request is based on salary and benefit calculations for specific roles. [4] The request details funding for one full-time equivalent for a temporary clinical psychologist position, a temporary social worker/human services professional IV position, and a temporary social services assistant V position. [4]
agency_impact: This measure was amended to include appropriations for both the Judiciary and the Department of Health. [4] The women's court pilot program shall be established within the second and fifth circuits of the judiciary. [3] The sums appropriated for specific clinical and social work positions shall be expended by the department of health for the purposes of this Act. [3]
economic_impact: The pilot program's goal is diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. [3] The measure seeks to address barriers such as lack of stable work history and economic marginalization to improve outcomes for women offenders. [4] This is based on research showing that gender-responsive approaches result in far better outcomes for women who face unique barriers to success after incarceration. [4]
policy_impact: This measure was amended by deleting language that would have established a three-year women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit of the Judiciary. [4] It instead requires the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint for a women's court pilot program in the third circuit. [3] The bill still requires the Judiciary to submit recommendations as to whether the pilot program should continue as a pilot program, expand, provide additional services, or be discontinued. [3]
revenue_sources: There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii an unspecified sum for the Judiciary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum for fiscal year 2026-2027. [3] A separate appropriation is made from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii for the Department of Health for the same fiscal years. [3] No other revenue sources are mentioned in the provided documents. [3]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The bill appropriates an unspecified sum from general revenues to the Judiciary for FY 2025-2026 and FY 2026-2027. [3] It also appropriates an unspecified sum from general revenues to the Department of Health for the same two fiscal years. [3] The committee report requests that the Finance Committee consider an appropriation of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) to the Department of Health. [4] This amount is intended to fund a 1.0 FTE temporary clinical psychologist position at $145,000 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt), a 1.0 FTE temporary social worker at $76,788 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt), and a 1.0 FTE temporary social services assistant at $45,216 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt). [4] The bill was amended to change the number of temporary staff positions established in the Judiciary to an unspecified amount. [4] The committee report also requests consideration for establishing seven temporary positions in the Judiciary. [4] The pilot program is established for three years and is set to be repealed on June 30, 2028. [3] The third circuit of the judiciary is required to submit a report on resource requirements for a future program. [3] Any fiscal implications beyond the pilot period are contingent on future legislative action. [3]
operating_revenue_impact: The provided legislative documents do not indicate any anticipated impact on operating revenues. [3] The bill is funded through appropriations from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [3] No fees, fines, or other revenue-generating mechanisms are mentioned. [3]
capital_expenditure_impact: The provided legislative documents do not specify any capital expenditures. [3] The appropriation for the Judiciary is for equipment, mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services, and the establishment of temporary positions. [3] No investments in facilities or major infrastructure are mentioned. [3]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The women's court pilot program is a temporary, three-year program that shall be repealed on June 30, 2028. [3] The judiciary is required to submit a report with recommendations as to whether the program should be continued, expanded, or discontinued. [3] Any fiscal obligations after the repeal date will depend on future legislation based on the program's outcomes and the judiciary's recommendations. [3]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The bill has been significantly amended since the previous version. [4] The pilot program's scope was reduced from the second, third, and fifth circuits to only the second and fifth circuits, with the third circuit now tasked with conducting a study. [4] A new appropriation for the Department of Health was inserted, and a committee report suggests an appropriation of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) to fund three positions. [4] The bill's effective date was changed from a fixed date to July 1, 3000, to encourage further discussion. [4]
fte_positions: The bill was amended by changing the number of temporary staff positions established in the Judiciary to an unspecified amount. [4] It newly provides for the establishment of temporary positions within the Department of Health. [3] A committee report requests funding for three specific temporary positions in the Department of Health: one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) clinical psychologist, one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) social worker/human services professional IV, and one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) social services assistant V. [4]
appropriations_changes: The bill was amended by inserting an appropriation for the Department of Health for the women's court pilot program. [4] This is in addition to the existing unspecified appropriation for the Judiciary. [3] A committee report requests that the Committee on Finance consider an appropriation amount of $801,802 (HB727_HD1_HSCR624_.htm.txt) to the Department of Health. [4]
funding_sources_changes: The method of funding has not changed. [3] Appropriations for both the Judiciary and the Department of Health are appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [3] There have been no changes to the funding source between versions of the bill. [3]
department_impact: Departmental responsibility for expending appropriations has been changed. [4] The bill was amended by inserting an appropriation for the Department of Health for the women's court pilot program. [4] The sums appropriated shall now be expended by both the judiciary and the department of health for the purposes of this Act. [3]
reports_required: A new reporting requirement has been added to the measure. [4] The third circuit of the judiciary shall submit a report of its findings and recommendations for establishing a pilot program to the legislature no later than twenty days prior to the convening of the regular session of 2026. [3] This is in addition to the annual reports from the judiciary on the status of the pilot program in the second and fifth circuits, which are due prior to the regular sessions of 2026, 2027, and 2028. [3]
pilot_program: The scope of the pilot program was amended. [4] The bill was changed by deleting language that would have established a three-year women's court pilot program in the Third Circuit of the Judiciary. [4] The pilot program is now established within the second and fifth circuits of the judiciary. [3]
sunset_date: The sunset date for the bill has not changed. [3] The Act shall be repealed on June 30, 2028. [3]
effective_date: The bill was amended by changing the effective date to July 1, 3000. [4] This change was made to encourage further discussion on the measure. [4]
